708385f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue & Broadway, north from 23rd Street, showing the intersection of these two arterial thoroughfares. To the left is the old Fifth Avenue Hotel; in the center is the Worth Monument; while on the right is Madison Square. Beyond the latter is the shadowy outline of the Marble Collegiate Church at 29th Street.

1860's

American Studio, photo
87 Nassau St. NYC

Gift of Urbrock Collection

708395f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue & Broadway, from 23rd (right) to 24th (left) Streets, showing the Fifth Avenue Hotel across a corner of Madison Square Park. To the right is the Albemarle Hotel at the N. W. corner of 24th Street. Note the absence of the upper story that appears in later views.
About 1860's
American Studio, photo
87 Nassau St., N.Y.C.
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RIGHTS UNKOWN

708399f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue & Broadway, north from 23rd Stree, showing an early view of this portion of the Madison Square locale. The latter is on the right bordered by Fifth Avenue. The triangular plot holding the Worth Monument separates this from Broadway. At the left margin is the old Fifth Avenue Hotel. In the background are two church spires, that on the left being the Broadway Tabernacle (Sixth Avenue & 34th St.) and the Marble Collegiate Dutch Church (Fifth Ave, & 29th St.) being on the right.
About 1860's

American Studio, photo
87 Nassau St, NYC

Gift of Urbrock Collection

708390f-a.text:
(1)
Fifth Ave., at the N.W. corner of West 23rd Street, showing two identical views of the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The hotel was opened in 1859, and became New York's foremost hostelry; having been visited by distinguished guests, such as the Prince of Wales, numerous United States Presidents, Ambassadors, and Emperors. The building was later demolished and on its site was later demolished and on its site was later erected the 14-story Fifth Ave. Building.
Prior to 1908.
August Loeffler
P. L. Sperr Collection.

(2)
The same.
About 1880.
Gift of H.D. Jewett.

The building was later demolished and on its site was later demolished and on its site was later erected the 14-story Fifth Ave. Building.

708383f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue (right) and Broadway (left) at 23rd Street, showing a triangular building site caused by the convergence of the first two thoroughfares upon which will soon rise the 21-story Fuller Building that is popularly known as the Flatiron Building because of its contour. Photographers vantage point is at 24th Street and he shows partially on the right the famous Fifth Ave. Hotel with its clock and lamps at the curbline. Construction work in the foreground may be the laying of car rails for the Broadway line which according to the New York Times of February 4, 1936 was built in 1885.

About 1885-90.
Brown Brothers.
Neg. #2604

711661f-a.text:
West 23rd Street, south side, east from a point between Sixth and Fifth Avenue's, and across the letter. This is to the left, where the Hotel Bartholdi appears at it's Broadway corner. Note the early store of Stern Brothers to the right.

February 1885

Gift of Urbrock Collection

708398f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue and Broadway, north from 23rd Street (intersection across the foreground), as photographed from Broadway. The Fifth Avenue Hotel is shown occupying the 23rd to 24th Street frontage, facing Madison Square Park (right). Note the cobblestone pavement, the gas lamps, horse drawn vehicles and the fencing around the Park. These in addition to the buildings shown have all disappeared. The surface car tracks are of the Broadway line and follow that thoroughfare to 26th Street where it regains its identity. The Worth Monument replaced by the Flatiron Building. Beyond the Fifth Avenue Hotel are the Albemarle and the Hoffman House. For a similar view at a later date see Kings' Handbook of New York 1892 - page 685.

About 1886

Gift of George T. Bagoe

Fifth Avenue and 23rd Street, showing the triumphal Arch for Washington 's inaugural Centennial.

April 29-30 1889

721485f.text:
Fifth Avenue and Broadway, north from 23rd Street and environs. From left to right respectively are Broadway, Fifth Avenue, Madison Square (Park) and the well known amusement center, Madison Square Garden. E. 26th Street forms the northerly rim of the park. In the right foreground is the seated statue of William Seward, Sec'y of State in President Lincoln's cabinet. The Worth monument is at the triangular apex formod by Broadway and Fifth Avenue. Prominent on the latter thoroughfare are, the Marble Collegiate Church, the Hotel Waldorf-Astoris and tho Prick Presbyterian Church.
1893
J. S. Johnston, photo
Copyright 1894
Ewing Galloway

708397f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue & Broadway, west side, from West 23rd to 24th Street's, showing the Fifth Avenue Hotel, opened in 1859 and removed in 1908. To the right is the Albemarle Hotel at the N.W. corner of 24th Street. This adjoins the world famous Hoffman House. To the left is W. 23rd Street, west of the Avenue. The photographers vantage point is obviously the Bartholdi Hotel at 23rd Street, as the apex formed by the convergence of Broadway and Fifth Avenue is in the lower left hand corner.

About 1894

Gift of Urbreck Collection

This photo is a companion to those that appeared on page 698 of the June 16, 1894 issue of the Illustrated American.
Vol. 15.
May 30, 1894.

711660f-a.text:
23rd Street east from between Sixth and Fifth Avenues. At the right foreground is Stern Brothers' Department Store, before it moved uptown to its 42nd Street location. At the left, on the N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue, is the famous Fifth Avenue Hotel, soon to give way to the Fifth Avenue Building. Beyond it may be seen very dimly the Metropolitan Life Insurance Building, and on the right, with the sign on its roof, the Bartholdi Building, formerly the Bartholdi Hotel. 1904.

Brown Brothers.

708377f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue (right) and Broadway (left) at 23rd Street, showing the triangular Fuller Building.  This structure, occupying the apex of this intersection is better known as the Flatiron building.

The vantage points for these views are at 25th and 26th  Streets and the direction is southward.  Note Madison Square (park) at left and the Fifth Avenue Hotel and Building (clock in front) at the right.

May be reproduced.  View 1: About 1905

P.L Sperr
No reproductions.  View 2: Fall 1925

E. L. Armbruster

*Slides in Public Education Division

708400f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, north from, but not including, 23rd Street, showing also the east side of Broadway from the same point. At the left is the famous New York landmark, the Fifth Avenue Hotel, built in 1859. It was considered one of the finest hotels in the world but its preeminence is being challenged by the new Waldorf-Astoria, a part of which shows in the centre background; and it is doomed to destruction in 1908. The row of white houses on the right is on the north side of 27th Street. From 26th to 27th Streets, hidden by the trees, is a clearing on the former site of the Brunswick Hotel, on which the new Brunswick Building will be erected.

About 1905.
Wurts Brothers.

708404f.text:
Fifth Avenue (right) and Broadway (left), north from 23rd Street as viewed from the Fuller (Flatiron) Building. Madison Square Park is to the right, opposite the triangular site where the Worth Mohument stands. To the lower left are, the old Fifth Avenue Hotel, the Albemarle and the Hoffman House. The Waldorf-Astoria appears at the upper right.
About 1905
Ewing Galloway

711662f-a.text:
49-51 West 23rd Street, north side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. By 1915, this will have been replaced by a twelve-story loft building.

About 1905.

708396f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, from 23rd to 24th Street, showing also a view of the north side of 23rd Street, facing west. The picture gives an excellent view of the 23rd Street, Fifth Avenue, and Broadway fronts of the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The scaffolding and chute at the left centre would indicate that demolition work on the famous old structure has actually begun. At any rate, it is abandoned, as its bare windows testify.
1908.
Brown Brothers.

708405f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue (right) and Broadway (left), north from 23rd Street, showing a safety zone where these two main thoroughfares intersect. In the center is the Worth Monument, while to the right appears a portion of Madison Square.
This photostat is one of a set depicting traffic conditions at various points and filed under their separate locations (Fifth Avenue) and Police Activities and are evidently part of a group published in March 11, 1909 issue - page 229.
About 1909
Leslies Weekly
Copyright-Judge Co.

721506f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, at the N.E. corner of East 23rd Street (right), showing an early automobilist being warned by a bicycle mounted police officer at Madison Square. Note the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. Tower under construction at the S.E. corner of Madison Avenue and E. 24th Street. To the left of same appears Dr. Parkhurst's Church and the insurance company's printing plant annex.
This photostat is one of a set filed under various Fifth Avenue locations and Police Activities and evidently was published for the latter purpose.
About 1909.
Leslies Weekly
Copyright - Judge Co.

721492f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., (left) at East 23rd Street (right), showing a view of Madison Square Park in a northeasterly direction and across it the tower of Madison Square Garden, on top of same is visible the famous bronze figure "Diana." Madison Square Garden was razed in 1926 and on its site was erected the 25-story New York Life Insurance Company Building.
About 1916.
Ewing Galloway.

721507f-a.text:
"Liberty Bank" in Madison Square, New York.  The structure is a miniature of the U.S. Sub-Treasury Building on Wall Street, and was erected by the Woman's Committee as a place to sell Liberty
Loan Bonds. The speaker is Mr. Job Hedges.
1917 Paul Thompson, photographer.

23rd Street at N.W. corner of Avenue A. The grounds of the animal hospital of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, Avenue A, west side, from 23rd to 24th Streets, may be seen.

In the foreground, appears Madison Square Park, with the flag pole bearing the "Eternal Light"; lit in commemoration of the supreme sacrifice of the American Expeditionary Forces in France.
March 12, 1929.

721518f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, south from 24th Street. At the right is the Fifth Avenue Building, which replaced the famous Fifth Avenue Hotel, and which it resembles, except in height. In the center is the Fuller, or Flatiron Building, whose fabulous height of 21 stories made it one of the sights of New York in other days. On the left is the statue of Admiral Farragut by the great American sculptor, Augustus St. Gaudens.
About 1924.

Ewing Galloway.

721521f.text:
Madison Square Park, bounded by Fifth Ave. (foreground) east to Madison Ave. and East 23rd (right) north to 26th Streets. Prior to 1806 this was a waste area, and in olden times a burial place for the poor. It was the site of a U.S. Arsenal, between 1806 to 1823. The first House of Refuge was founded here in 1825, which burned down in 1839. During the Ma7oralty of CJames Harper (one of the famous publishers), between 1844 and 1847; this dreary region was cleared and beautified, and became the famous Madison Square. To-day this park is surrounded by large buildings, of which the Madison Ave. contingent predominates; possessing, as it does the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. Buildings and Tower; the Madison Ave. Building, the Appellate division Supreme Court; the 1anhattan Club and the New York Life Insurance Co. guilding.  The William H. Seward Statue shown in the foreground, (N.E. oorner of Fifth Ave. and East 23rd StrSet), was unveiled in 1876, and is inscribed: dGowernor, D.S. Senattr, Secretary of State U.S.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

721522f-a.text:
General Views:

(1) Tower of Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, at left on Madison, at right Flatiron Building at intersection of Fifth Avenue and Broadway, looking south.
NEG#3642

(2) Madison Square looking west across Fifth Avenue. Flatiron Building shown at intersection of Broadway and Fifth Avenue.
